title: A possible new approach to learning more about the chemical make-up of the Shroud’s image
post:
To summarise: it would be difficult, perhaps well-nigh impossible, to discover how the imaging process has altered the surface carbohydrates of the Shroud. The chemistry is too complex – especially if as seems probable the tan-coloured image consists of high-molecular weight condensation polymers. There is an alternative strategy – which is to obtain profiles of unaltered carbohydrates, and to deduce (by comparison with non-image areas) which classes of carbohydrates have been modified. The technology to do that exists, although it will  be destructive.
One could speculate that it is the chemically more reactive (5-carbon) pentosans of the primary cell wall that are modified, with the  chemically-stable more ordered cellulose fibres being largely unaffected. 
Xylan polymers might de-polymerise, releasing free xylose that then dehydrates to furfural, the latter then oxidising and polymerising via condensation reactions to give the yellow and tan products (see the Comments above for details).
author: colinsberry
